ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Incredibly growth in written and spoken French. Felt my confidence in French grammar take great strides.

In addition to strengthening my reading, writing, and speaking skills, I gained exposure to amazing literary works including the short stories by renowned Francophone authors and the two full-length novels that we read in this class.
This was a good course for improving my French and continuing to improve the consistency of my grammatical and speaking skills, as well as reading and vocabulary.
strengthening french skills, widening vocabulary, adopting a more structured disciplined approach to learning language

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Well structured syllabus with predictable homework and exams. Strong professor who seemed to really care about their students.

Weaknesses: Infrequent/ not marketed office hours, difficult to get a tutor.

I appreciated the multitude of exercises and readings we did in this class. While it was a lot of work, they helped me grasp the content and feel prepared for the exams. However at certain times, the required daily homework felt overwhelming. I would recommend spacing out the assigned homework and readings so that it remains under two hours a day while still covering all of the topics in the class.

Like all language courses, especially in the French department, this course has the challenge of teaching an extensive amount of material in a short amount of time. Sometimes this causes the workload to fluctuate or rise to a level that makes it impractical to do all of the exercises when combined with a full schedule.

everyday class is both a strength and weakness, i just wish it was set at later times and not all in the morning.
i hope the course schedule was more organized, and the canvas interface was more optimal and organized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you would like to greatly increase fluency, fulfill a language requirement, or go on to L5 (that is if you have the time to dedicate to the work!).

I would recommend this course to students who want to improve their French language abilities and gain exposure to vibrant and important literary works by Francophone authors. The French department at Yale is difficult, and this class is no exception. Nevertheless, the professor is very supportive and committed to helping all students who take this course to succeed.
If the student either has to take this course or has a sincere interest in improving their course then I could recommend this.
